source: Based on Thomas W. Higginson translation (1865) of Epictetus

chapters.content:
Some things are within your control, and some things are not. Within your control are your thoughts, your impulses, your desires, and your aversions—in short, everything that is truly your own doing. Outside your control are your body, your possessions, your reputation, your job—in short, everything that is not truly your own doing.

The things within your control are naturally free, unrestricted, and unimpeded. The things outside your control are fragile, dependent, easily blocked, and ultimately belong to others. Remember: if you treat things outside your control as if they were within it, you will meet obstacles everywhere, you will grieve, you will be anxious, and you will blame both fate and other people. But if you recognize that only what is truly yours is yours, no one will ever be able to force you or hold you back. You will blame no one, accuse no one, do nothing against your will. No one will harm you, and you will have no enemies.

So if you're aiming for these great things—freedom, peace, equanimity—understand that you can't pursue them half-heartedly while also chasing external prizes. You must choose. If you try to have both inner freedom and worldly success, you'll likely fail at both. But if you focus on what's within your control, you can actually achieve happiness.

Whenever something troubles you, practice this: examine it and ask yourself whether it concerns something within your control or outside it. If it's outside your control, remind yourself: "This is not my concern."

Remember: desire wants to obtain what it desires, and aversion wants to avoid what it dislikes. When we fail to get what we desire, we're disappointed. When we encounter what we want to avoid, we're miserable.

So if you only try to avoid things that are within your control—your own harmful choices and bad judgments—you'll never encounter what you're trying to avoid. But if you try to avoid things outside your control—illness, death, poverty—you'll constantly be running into what you fear.

For now, put aside desire entirely. If you desire things outside your control, you're guaranteed to be disappointed. And you're not yet skilled enough to reliably desire the right things within your control. Instead, focus simply on gently steering away from the things within your control that would harm you. Be moderate and calm in how you go about this.

Whenever you enjoy something—whether it's a useful object, a cherished possession, or a person you love—remind yourself of what it truly is. Start with small things: if you have a favorite coffee mug, acknowledge that it's just a mug. Then if it breaks, you won't be devastated.

When you hug your child or your partner, remind yourself that you're embracing a mortal human being. Then if they die, you'll be able to bear it.

Before you start any activity, consider what it really involves. If you're going to the gym, picture the whole experience—people hogging equipment, others being loud or rude, the frustrations that come with crowded spaces. That way you can say to yourself: "I'm going to work out, but I'm also going to maintain my composure no matter what happens."

Apply this to everything you do. Then when obstacles arise, you can tell yourself: "I wasn't just here to accomplish this task. I was here to keep my mind steady and aligned with my values. And I won't maintain that equilibrium if I let myself get upset over minor annoyances."

It's not events that disturb us, but our judgments about events. Death, for example, is not inherently terrifying—if it were, Socrates would have feared it. What terrifies us is our belief that death is terrible.

So whenever we feel blocked, upset, or distressed, let's not blame external circumstances or other people. Let's look at our own judgments. An untrained person blames others for their problems. Someone beginning their training blames themselves. Someone who has completed their training blames neither others nor themselves.

Don't take pride in qualities that aren't really yours. If a horse could boast and say, "I'm beautiful," that might make sense—beauty is a quality of the horse. But when you boast about having a beautiful horse, you're taking pride in something that belongs to the horse, not to you.

What actually belongs to you? How you use and respond to what happens. When you handle life's circumstances with wisdom and integrity, then you have something to genuinely feel good about—because that's truly your own achievement.

Life is like being on a voyage. When the ship anchors and you go ashore, you might pick up some shells or interesting rocks along the way. But keep your attention on the ship, always listening for the captain's call. When you hear it, drop everything and run back—don't look behind you, or you'll be carried aboard like cargo.

It's the same with life. If you're given a spouse or a child, enjoy them. But when life calls you back—when circumstances change, when death approaches—go without clinging. And if you're getting older, don't stray too far from the ship. You don't want to miss the call.
Don't demand that events happen as you wish. Instead, wish for them to happen as they do happen, and you'll be at peace.

Illness can limit your body, but it doesn't have to limit your will—unless you let it. A leg injury hampers your leg, not your character.

Apply this principle to everything that happens. You'll find that each obstacle affects something external, but your inner self remains untouched—unless you choose otherwise.

For every challenge you face, look inward and find the strength you have to deal with it. Encountering someone attractive? You have self-discipline. Facing pain? You have endurance. Dealing with insults? You have patience.

Make this a habit, and life's challenges will never overwhelm you.

Never say "I've lost something." Say instead, "I've returned it." Has your child died? They've been returned. Has your spouse died? They've been returned. Has your property been taken? That too has been returned.

"But the person who took it was terrible!" What does it matter to you through whose hands the universe reclaims what it gave? For as long as something is entrusted to you, treat it like a traveler treats a hotel room—use it, but know it was never really yours.

If you want to make progress, let go of thoughts like: "If I don't obsess over my business, I'll go broke" or "If I don't micromanage my employees, they'll slack off." It's better to be poor and free from anxiety than rich and constantly worried. It's better to have imperfect employees than to make yourself miserable through control.

Start with small things. Some olive oil gets spilled? Some wine goes missing? Tell yourself: "This is the price of peace of mind. Nothing is free." When you call for someone and they don't come right away—or they don't do exactly what you want—remember: they're not powerful enough to actually disturb your peace. Only you can do that.

If you want to grow, be willing to seem foolish and clueless about worldly matters. Don't try to appear knowledgeable. If others think you're somebody important, be skeptical of yourself.

Understand: it's hard to keep your inner life aligned with wisdom while also chasing external success. If you focus on one, you'll inevitably neglect the other.

It's foolish to wish that your spouse, children, and friends will live forever—you're wishing for control over things that aren't up to you, and for things that belong to others to be yours. It's equally foolish to expect that your employees will never make mistakes—you're wishing that human flaws didn't exist.

But wishing to never be disappointed? That you can actually control, because it depends on your own desires. So work on what you can actually change.

Your master is anyone who has power over the things you're attached to. If you want to be free, don't let your wellbeing depend on anything outside your control.

Approach life like a guest at a dinner party. When a dish comes around to you, reach out and take a reasonable portion. When it passes by, don't grab at it. When it hasn't arrived yet, don't yearn for it—wait for it to reach you.

Apply this to family, career, money, status. Take what comes with grace, and you'll be worthy to dine with the wise. But if you can go further—if you can actually decline what's offered, not needing it at all—then you won't just be a worthy guest. You'll be able to host the feast yourself.

When you see someone grieving—over a child who moved away, or a loss in business—be careful not to get swept up in their emotional interpretation. What's actually hurting them isn't the event itself (someone else in the same situation might not be bothered at all), but their judgment about the event.

Still, don't be cold. In conversation, meet them where they are. Sympathize, even groan along with them if the situation calls for it. Just don't let the groaning reach your inner self.

Remember: you're an actor in a play, and the playwright has determined the role. If it's a short part, it's short. If it's long, it's long. If you're cast as a poor person, a disabled person, a leader, or an ordinary citizen—play that role well.

Your job is to act your given part skillfully. Choosing the part? That's someone else's responsibility.

When something happens that seems like a bad omen—a black cat crosses your path, you spill salt, whatever—don't let appearances run away with you. Tell yourself: "This doesn't actually mean anything bad for me, my body, my possessions, my reputation, my family. Every omen can be favorable if I choose to make good use of whatever happens."

You can be undefeatable—if you never enter a contest where winning isn't up to you. When you see someone with power, prestige, or privilege, be careful not to automatically assume they're happy or enviable. If what's truly good is within your control, there's no room for envy.

Don't wish to be a CEO, a celebrity, or a senator. Wish to be free. And the only path to freedom is letting go of attachment to things outside your control.

Remember: the person who insults or hits you isn't what really offends you. It's your judgment that these things are offensive. When someone provokes you, recognize that it's your own opinion doing the provoking.

So first, try not to get swept away by your initial impression. If you can pause and create some space, you'll find it much easier to stay in control of yourself.

Keep death and loss before your eyes every day—along with everything else people consider terrible. But especially death. When you do this, you'll never have a petty thought, and you won't crave anything too desperately.

If you're serious about philosophy and wisdom, be prepared from the start for mockery. People will say, "Look who suddenly became a philosopher!" and "Where did that superior attitude come from?"

Don't actually have a superior attitude. Just stick to what seems right to you, as if you've been assigned to this post. Remember: if you stay committed, the same people who mocked you will eventually admire you. But if you give in to their pressure, you'll earn double ridicule.

If you ever find yourself caring about external things to please someone else, know that you've abandoned your path. Be content with being someone who values wisdom and inner growth. If you want to appear that way to others, first appear that way to yourself—and that will be enough.

Don't let thoughts like these bother you: "I'll be nobody, I'll have no status anywhere." If having no status is bad, then others can't make you experience something bad any more than they can make you do something shameful. Is it your job to get power or party invitations? Of course not. So how is not having these things a disgrace?

"But I won't be able to help my friends!" What do you mean, help them? They won't get money from you or social connections through you. But who said those things are your responsibility? How can you give others what you don't have yourself?

"Get money then," they say, "so you can share with us." If I can get money while maintaining my integrity and peace of mind, show me how—I'll do it. But if you're asking me to sacrifice what's good in myself so you can get things that aren't even truly good, think about how unreasonable that is.

Which would you rather have: money, or a loyal friend with integrity? Help me become that kind of person instead of asking me to do things that would destroy those qualities.

"But what about serving my community?" Again—what service do you mean? Your community won't get new buildings or bathhouses from you. So what? It doesn't get shoes from the baker or weapons from the shoemaker either. Everyone contributing their best work is enough. If you contribute another person of integrity and good judgment, isn't that useful?

"But what position will I have?" Whatever position you can hold while maintaining your character. If trying to be useful causes you to lose your integrity, how can you help anyone once you've become corrupt?

Someone got promoted over you, or was honored at a party, or consulted before you were. If these things are good, be glad they received them. If they're bad, don't be upset that you didn't.

Remember: you can't get the same results as people who do things you won't do. Someone who flatters the boss, hangs around constantly, heaps on praise—how can someone who doesn't do these things expect the same treatment? It would be unfair and greedy to expect equal rewards without paying equal costs.

At the market, lettuce costs money. If someone pays and gets lettuce while you keep your money and don't, they haven't gained an advantage over you. They have lettuce; you have your money.

It works the same way socially. You weren't invited to someone's dinner party? You didn't pay the price of admission—which is flattery, attention, praise. If it's worth it to you, pay up. But if you want to keep your dignity and also get the invitation, you want it both ways.

What do you have instead of the dinner? You have: not having to praise someone you'd rather not praise, and not having to put up with their insufferable friends.

Nature's intentions can be understood from everyday situations we all agree on. When your neighbor's kid breaks a cup, you're quick to say, "These things happen." Apply the same wisdom when your own cup breaks.

Scale this up to bigger things. When someone else's child or spouse dies, everyone says, "That's part of being human." But when our own loved one dies, we immediately cry, "Why me? How terrible!"

Remember how you feel about others' misfortunes, and try to feel the same way about your own.

Just as targets aren't set up so that people will miss them, the nature of evil doesn't exist in the world as a fundamental feature. Things we call "evil" are usually just obstacles to be worked through or avoided.

If someone handed your body over to a random stranger, you'd be furious. So why aren't you ashamed when you hand your mind over to anyone who wants to upset it? All someone has to do is insult you, and you let them take control of your mental state.

Before undertaking anything, consider what comes before and after, then proceed. Otherwise, you'll start with enthusiasm, then quit when the real demands become clear.

"I want to win at the Olympics." Fine—but consider what that really means. You need to follow strict discipline, eat according to a plan, train whether you feel like it or not, in heat and cold. No alcohol, no junk food. You submit completely to your coach like a patient to a doctor. Then in competition, you might get injured, swallow dust, get knocked down—and still lose.

Think about all of this. If you still want it, go for it. Otherwise, you're being childish—like kids who play at being wrestlers one moment, gladiators the next, musicians after that, actors later. You become whatever you most recently admired, but nothing seriously.

This is how people become half-hearted philosophers. They hear a compelling speaker, get inspired, and want to be philosophers too. But consider what it actually requires. It's like wanting to be an athlete—first examine your abilities. Different people are built for different things.

Do you think you can live as you do now and be a philosopher? That you can eat, drink, lose your temper, and indulge yourself the same way? You'll need to work hard, give up some pleasures, study, accept that some people will look down on you, come off worse in status competitions.

Once you've considered all this, proceed if you still want to. But choose: wisdom or worldly success. You can't have both. You must be one person—developing your inner self, or chasing external things. Be a philosopher or be part of the crowd. But don't switch back and forth.

Our duties are defined by our relationships. Someone is your parent? This implies taking care of them, accepting their authority, enduring their criticism gracefully. "But they're a bad parent!" The universe didn't promise you a good parent—just a parent.

Your sibling is treating you badly? Maintain your role as a good sibling regardless. Focus not on what they do, but on what you must do to keep yourself aligned with your values. No one else can truly harm you unless you let them. You're only harmed when you decide to feel harmed.

Practice this with every relationship—neighbor, colleague, boss—and you'll understand your proper duties in each case.

The core of genuine spirituality lies in this: holding correct beliefs about how the universe operates—that there's an underlying order, and it runs fairly. Commit yourself to accepting and working with that order, following it willingly through whatever happens, trusting that it reflects a deeper wisdom.

This way, you'll never resent the way things are or feel neglected by existence.

But this is only possible if you stop placing good and evil in things outside your control. If you think external things are good or bad, then whenever you don't get what you want or get what you don't want, you'll inevitably blame the source. Every creature naturally avoids what seems harmful and pursues what seems beneficial.

So it's impossible to feel grateful toward someone you think is harming you—just as it's impossible to enjoy the harm itself. This is why even children resent parents who don't give them what they want. What made enemies of Polynices and Eteocles? The belief that kingship was good. It's why people complain about their circumstances—our care follows our interests.

Whoever properly manages their desires and aversions is also cultivating genuine spirituality. And when it comes to traditional rituals and observances, participate with sincerity, presence, and appropriate generosity—neither stingily nor extravagantly.

When you seek guidance from any source—whether astrology, therapy, or advice from others—remember: you went because you didn't know the outcome, but you already knew what kind of thing it was. If it's outside your control, it can't be truly good or bad for your character.

So don't approach guidance with desperate hopes or fears—that makes you tremble before the answer. Understand first that any outcome is workable, and no one can stop you from using it well. Then seek counsel with confidence.

Afterward, honor the guidance you receive. Don't ignore advice and then wonder why you bothered asking.

Use guidance for situations where logic and skill can't determine the answer. But for clear moral questions—whether to stand by a friend in danger, whether to support what's right—don't consult oracles or advisors. Even if the signs are bad, reason tells you: stand by your friends, support what's right. That's the best guidance of all.

Establish a character and a way of being that you maintain whether alone or with others.

Be mostly quiet, or speak only what's necessary, briefly. Occasionally engage in conversation when appropriate, but don't let it drift toward gossip about celebrities, sports statistics, food and drink, or the usual small talk—especially don't gossip about people, either criticizing or praising them or comparing them to others. If you can, steer conversations toward meaningful topics. If you're stuck with people focused on trivial things, stay silent.

Don't laugh too loudly, too often, or too easily.

Avoid making promises and swearing to things whenever possible.

Avoid mainstream entertainment as much as practical. But if you attend something, stay alert and don't let yourself get swept into the crowd's reactions. If something is genuinely pure and you encounter it, guard against it corrupting you—because anyone you spend time with influences you.

Meet your body's needs—food, drink, clothes, housing—but cut out everything that's about display or luxury.

Regarding intimacy, stay disciplined before marriage. Don't judge those who are more permissive, and don't make a show of your own restraint.

If someone tells you that another person was talking badly about you, don't make excuses for what was said. Just respond: "They must not know about my other faults, or they would have mentioned those too."

You don't need to attend every event or show. But when you go, don't cheer for anyone except yourself—meaning, wish only for things to go exactly as they go, and for the most deserving to win. Don't shout or get overly emotional, and afterward don't talk endlessly about what happened unless it somehow made you better.

When meeting with someone who has authority over you, imagine how Socrates or another wise person would handle it. You'll find a way to conduct yourself appropriately.

When you need something from a powerful person, prepare yourself for the possibility of being ignored, turned away, or treated dismissively. If it's still worth going, go—and whatever happens, don't tell yourself it wasn't worth the trouble. That's the thinking of someone controlled by external things.

In conversation, don't constantly talk about your own experiences and achievements. What's interesting to you isn't equally interesting to others. Don't try too hard to be funny—it can come across as crude and lower others' respect for you. And stay away from vulgar or inappropriate topics. If someone else goes there, show your disapproval through silence or a look of discomfort.

When a pleasure presents itself, don't let it carry you away immediately. Let it wait while you pause and give yourself time. Then consider two moments: the moment of enjoying the pleasure, and the moment afterward when you might regret it or think less of yourself. Weigh these against the satisfaction and self-respect you'll feel if you abstain.

Even if it seems like the right time to indulge, be careful of its charm and sweetness. Consider how much better it feels to know you won this small victory over yourself.

When you're convinced something is the right thing to do, do it—even if others might misunderstand. If it's actually wrong, don't do it at all. But if it's right, why worry about people who will judge you incorrectly?

"It's day or it's night" makes sense as a logical distinction, but not as a combination. Similarly, at a shared meal, taking the largest portion might make sense from a pure appetite perspective, but it's completely wrong from a social perspective.

When eating with others, consider not just what the food is worth to your body, but what maintaining respect for your host and fellow guests is worth.
If you take on a role that's beyond your current capacity, you both fail at that role and miss the opportunity to succeed at a role you could have handled.

Just as you watch where you step to avoid twisting your ankle, watch your decisions to avoid harming your judgment and character. If we applied this level of care to every action, we'd move through life much more safely.

Your body is the natural measure of what you need—like a foot is the measure of a shoe. If you stick to this, you'll stay balanced. But if you go beyond it, you'll slide down a slippery slope.

It's like shoes: first you want comfortable ones, then stylish ones, then designer ones, then encrusted with jewels. Once you exceed what you actually need, there's no natural limit.

From an early age, people are often valued primarily for their appearance. Perceiving this, they naturally focus on appearance and learn to see it as their main source of worth.

We should work to ensure that people—especially young people—understand they're valued for their character and actions, not just how they look.

Spending excessive time on bodily concerns—too much exercise, too much attention to eating and drinking, too much focus on physical functions—is a sign of misplaced priorities.

These things should be handled quickly and simply, with your main energy directed toward developing your mind and character.

When someone treats you badly or speaks badly about you, remember that they're acting from their own sense of what's right. They can't follow your sense of right—only their own. So if their perception is mistaken, they're the one who's hurt by being deceived.

If someone thinks a true statement is false, the statement isn't harmed—only the person who's wrong is harmed. Starting from this understanding, you'll respond gently to critics. With each offense, tell yourself: "That's how it seemed to them."

Everything has two handles: one that makes it bearable, one that makes it unbearable. If your sibling wrongs you, don't grab the handle of "my sibling wronged me"—that's the unbearable handle. Instead, grab the other handle: "this is my sibling, someone I grew up with." That's the one you can actually hold.

These arguments don't follow: "I'm richer than you, therefore I'm better than you." "I'm more articulate than you, therefore I'm better than you."

What actually follows: "I'm richer than you, therefore my possessions are greater." "I'm more articulate than you, therefore my speaking is superior."

But you are neither your possessions nor your speaking ability.

Someone takes quick showers? Don't say they shower badly—say they shower quickly. Someone drinks a lot? Don't say they drink badly—say they drink a lot.

Until you understand someone's reasons, how do you know it's actually bad? This way, you won't react to things based on superficial impressions while missing what's actually going on.

Never call yourself a philosopher or talk much about philosophical principles with people who won't understand. Just act on those principles. At a dinner, don't lecture on proper eating—just eat properly.

Remember that Socrates had so completely eliminated showing off that when people came wanting to be introduced to philosophers, he would introduce them to others—he was that comfortable being overlooked.

When conversation among non-philosophers turns to philosophical topics, mostly stay quiet. There's great risk in immediately talking about what you haven't fully absorbed. When someone says you don't know anything, and you don't feel stung by it, then you're actually making progress.

Sheep don't throw up their grass to show the shepherd how much they've eaten. They digest their food internally and produce wool and milk externally. Similarly, don't display your philosophical principles to others. Display the actions that emerge from having digested them.

Once you've gotten used to living simply, don't show it off. If you only drink water, don't announce at every opportunity: "I only drink water." Consider that poor people live far more simply than you and endure far more hardship.

If you want to train yourself to handle discomfort, do it for yourself, not as a performance. When you're really thirsty, try taking cold water in your mouth and spitting it out—and tell no one.

The mark of an ordinary person: they never expect benefit or harm from themselves, only from external things.

The mark of a philosopher: they expect all benefit and harm from themselves.

Signs of someone making progress: they criticize no one, praise no one, blame no one, accuse no one, say nothing about themselves as if they were important or knew something special. When blocked or frustrated, they blame themselves. If praised, they privately laugh at the person praising them. If criticized, they don't defend themselves.

They move through life like someone recovering from illness—carefully, not wanting to disturb what's starting to heal before it's strong. They've removed craving, and they've shifted their aversion away from things outside their control to focus only on what contradicts their own nature within their control.

They go easy on themselves in all things. If they seem stupid or ignorant, they don't care. In short, they watch themselves like someone keeping an eye on a potential enemy.

When someone takes pride in being able to understand and explain difficult philosophical texts, tell yourself: "If these texts weren't written in a challenging way, this person would have nothing to be proud of."

But what do I actually want? To understand how to live well. So I look for someone who can teach me that. I hear that certain philosophers can, so I go to their writings. But I don't understand them, so I look for someone to explain them. Up to here, there's nothing to be proud of.

When I find an interpreter, what matters is putting the teachings into practice. This alone is worth something. If I merely admire the interpretation itself, I've just become a literary critic instead of a philosopher.

The only difference is that I'm analyzing philosophy books instead of poetry. So when someone asks me to explain a text, I feel more embarrassed than proud—because what I really should be showing is not my understanding of the text, but my actions that align with what the text teaches.

Whatever principles you've adopted, follow them as if they were laws that would be wrong to break—and don't worry about what anyone says about you, because that's not your concern.

How much longer will you put off demanding the best from yourself? You've been given the principles. You have what you need. What kind of teacher are you waiting for? You're not a child anymore. You're an adult.

If you keep procrastinating, keep making excuses, keep saying "I'll start tomorrow" and "I'll get serious next week," you won't make progress. You'll go through life as an ordinary person and die as one.

Right now—this moment—decide to live as someone who's capable of excellence. Let whatever seems best to you be your unbreakable law. When something difficult or pleasurable or prestigious or ignoble comes your way, remember: the contest is now. The Olympics are happening. You can't delay anymore.

Progress is either won or lost based on a single day, a single moment. This is how Socrates became who he was—by taking every situation as an opportunity to work with his principles.

You're not Socrates yet. But you should live like someone who wants to become Socrates.

The first and most important part of philosophy is actually applying principles—for example, that we should not lie. The second is understanding why—why shouldn't we lie? The third is what gives the other two their foundation—what makes this a valid proof? What is proof? What is logical consistency? What is truth? What is falsehood?

So the third level is necessary because of the second, and the second because of the first. But the most essential—the one we should spend the most time on—is the first: actually applying the principles.

We typically do the opposite. We spend all our time on the third level, mastering logical theory, while completely neglecting the first. So we can give eloquent explanations for why lying is wrong—while we continue to lie.

Keep these reminders at hand:

"Lead me, O Universe, and you, O Destiny, wherever you have assigned me. I will follow without hesitation; and even if I resist, I will have to follow anyway."

"Whoever yields gracefully to necessity is wise and understands what truly matters."

And from Socrates: "Crito, if this is what the universe requires, then let it be so. Anytus and Melitus can kill me, but they cannot harm me."
